III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Leppien Passages program is a large building that is located across the parking lot
from Holbrock, the main office building for Eagle Village. This 15-bed facility is
located on 681 acres in Osceola County, in Hersey, Michigan. The common
area/living room greets you as you enter the building. There are couches, chairs and
large windows that overlook the lake and into the woods. There is a large kitchen,
medical staff/supervisor office and therapist office connected to the common
area/living room. Medications are administered from the medical staff/supervisor
office. There is a large media room adjacent to the common area/living room. The
media room has televisions and seating around the outside of the room.
There are two hallways upon entering the house. Each hallway consists of five
bedrooms, one bathroom and a laundry room. There are ten bedrooms total in the
house, all furnished with beds and dressers. Leppien Passages will have a female
hallway and male hallway. The bedrooms can have one or two same gender youth
to a room depending upon the room size.
B. Program Description
2

The Leppien Passages Program is a Mental Health/Behavior Stabilization residential
program designed to equip and prepare teens, ages 14-17, for a successful
transition to adulthood and community living. Full assessment of academic and
vocational readiness, life skills, personal care and decision making are combined
with education and training to incorporate daily opportunities to learn and apply
independent living skills.
Trauma informed individual and group therapy, vocational opportunities and daily
decision making and planning, help each teen craft a path for success and prepare
for future independence. On-campus paid job opportunities present real work
experience to prepare for off-campus employment.
Passages (15 bed maximum) is a co-ed, 6-to-12-month program that is designed to
serve abused and neglected males and females, who cannot or are not ready, to
return to their own families, foster care, group home or independent living.
Passages is focused on stabilizing teens’ behaviors and medications, while setting
them up for future success. Passages will accept teens provided they meet the
admissions criteria, participate in an assessment interview, and are motivated to
work towards independence.
Academic assessment is completed upon admission into Passages to ensure that
each teens’ educational needs are met while attending Lighthouse Academy, a
charter school (chartered through Ferris State University) on the campus of Eagle
Village. Lighthouse Academy provides a full academic program including Individual
Education Plans and credit recovery, to ensure opportunity for High School
graduation.
Teens’ vocational readiness is also assessed for participation in the on-campus
Career and Trades Program, which focuses on certifications, developing workplace
soft skills such as teamwork, communication, problem solving and work ethic.
The Passages program team is comprised of two Masters Level Family Therapists,
a Certified Therapeutic Recreation Specialist and a Residential House Supervisor.
The Passages Family Therapists will utilize trauma informed therapies to provide
youth with weekly individual counseling, weekly group counseling, and be an
advocate for youth within their community. In addition to therapy, goals are
individualized and oriented toward each teen’s specific and future needs.
The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:3 during awake hours and 1:6 during sleeping hours.
The facility will have no form of seclusion for the youth. Facility staff will be trained
in the use of Aegis for de-escalation and restraint purposes.

There are currently no rule/statutory violations.
